title-group.article-title: A spatio-temporal reconstruction of Holocene temperature change in southern Scandinavia

article-meta.aff: 2Geological Survey of Denmark and Greenland, Denmark
6University College London and University of Oxford, UK

abstract.p: Holocene mean July (TJul) and mean January (TJan) temperatures were reconstructed at Lake Trehörningen in southwest Sweden using pollen–climate calibration functions and converted into anomalies relative to modern temperatures. The anomalies were applied to 28 meteorological stations in Denmark, with each station adjusted to account for spatial variability in both TJul and TJan. The resulting reconstructions were merged to create composite TJul and TJan records. The individual reconstructions were also used to establish the parameterization of the TJul and TJan values, resulting in Holocene temperature maps for all of Denmark. Low TJul values characterised southern Sweden and Denmark at the start of the Holocene, followed by an increase during the early Holocene. Likewise, TJan was initially low at the start of the Holocene, followed by an increase between 10 500 and 9900 cal. BP. Thereafter, TJan was relatively stable between 9900 and 8000 cal. BP. The general increase in temperature during the early Holocene was accompanied by a decrease in the amplitude of the mean monthly temperature record, indicating that a maritime climate was established at this time. Maximum TJul and TJan are recorded during the mid-Holocene interval from 8000 to 4500 cal. BP, with consistently high July temperatures (>18°C) between 6700 and 5400 cal. BP. During the late Holocene, both TJul and TJan gradually decreased. The Holocene temperature maps of Denmark reveal spatial patterns in both summer and winter temperature. In the summer, an east–west decreasing temperature gradient, related to a maritime effect, has persisted in Denmark throughout the Holocene. In contrast, the temperature in winter has varied spatially along subtle coastal–inland and topographical gradients. Various mechanisms have been invoked to explain the Holocene trends in temperature, including the melting of the Scandinavian Ice Sheet, changes in insolation, and changes in the dominant type of atmospheric circulation affecting northern Europe.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A primary objective in terrestrial palaeoecology is to use fossil plant remains to examine the origin, development and dynamics of plant communities through time (Birks, 1986; Iversen, 1973). Considering that plant distribution and abundance patterns are strongly influenced by climate (Willis and McElwain, 2002; Woodward, 1987), fossil plant records are also often used to examine past changes in climate (Birks and Seppä, 2010; Bradley, 1999; McElwain et al., 1999), achieved using qualitative or quantitative approaches. Qualitative reconstruction typically utilizes either an indicator or assemblage approach (Birks, 2003; Birks et al., 2010; Iversen, 1944, 1960, 1973), whereby the climatological preferences of a fossilized indicator species or assemblage are used to evaluate past climate. Qualitative climate reconstruction has since been augmented by quantitative approaches (Birks, 1998, 2003; Birks et al., 2010) that use modern climate calibration sets to infer past climates (Brown et al., 2006; Heusser et al., 1980; Seppä and Birks, 2001). In this approach, the climate reconstruction is achieved by applying climate calibration functions to fossil pollen data, or other suitable proxies. Critically, this approach requires high quality modern and fossil data sets that are based on consistent biological taxonomy, as well as reliable and representative climate data (Birks et al., 2010).

The recent development of a modern pollen–climate calibration set in Fennoscandia (Seppä and Birks, 2001; Seppä et al., 2004) has facilitated several quantitative climate reconstructions in northern Europe (Antonsson and Seppä, 2007; Antonsson et al., 2006, 2008; Bjune et al., 2004, 2005; Seppä et al., 2005, 2009a). In general, these studies have focused on reconstructing Holocene trends in either annual or summer temperature, largely because the growing season temperature, which exhibits a strong correlation with mean summer temperature (Antonsson et al., 2008), is a highly influential factor regulating plant distribution, growth and pollen productivity in northern Europe (Birks, 1981). The reconstructions exhibit a comparable pattern of Holocene temperature change whereby low but increasing temperatures characterize the early Holocene from 11 500 to 8000 calendar years before present (cal. BP). Maximum temperatures are thereafter observed during the mid-Holocene interval from c. 8000 to 5000 cal. BP. In contrast to mid-Holocene warmth, the late-Holocene interval (c. 5000 cal. BP–present) is characterized by a long-term cooling trend. Superimposed on this trend are several centennial- to millennial-scale climatic anomalies (Seppä et al., 2009a). Warmer periods are evident between 5000 and 4000 cal. BP, and 3000 and 1000 cal. BP, as well as during the last 150 years, with the 3000–1000 cal. BP anomaly incorporating both the ‘Roman Warm Period’ as well as the ‘Medieval Warm Period’. In comparison, colder periods prevailed between 3800 and 3000 cal. BP, and 500 and 100 cal. BP, with the latter anomaly corresponding to the ‘Little Ice Age’ in northern Europe.

In contrast, only a few studies have focused on Holocene trends in winter temperature (Giesecke et al., 2008; Iversen, 1944). The general lack of winter temperature reconstruction in Fennoscandia is related to the fact that the vegetation is generally dormant and biologically inactive during the winter. However, southern Scandinavia differs from northern Fennoscandia in that it is characterized by a maritime climate that supports many plant species and communities that are unable to tolerate winter frost and are thus dependant on mild winters (Dahl, 1998). Given this difference, winter temperature may be reconstructed using pollen records from southern Scandinavia, assuming that the maritime plant communities and species that persist under mild conditions will decline under cooler temperatures. In a pioneering investigation, Iversen (1944) developed thermal-limit curves for three maritime plants (Ilex aquifolium, Hedera helix and Viscum album) and then combined those curves with plant distribution and pollen data to deduce past climates. The results suggested that both summer and winter temperatures were warmer in Denmark between c. 9000 and 5900 cal. BP, followed a decrease in winter temperatures to below present-day values between 5900 and 2500 cal. BP. During the last 2500 years, summer temperatures decreased whereas winter temperatures increased. More recently, Giesecke et al. (2008) reconstructed several climate components across central Fennoscandia, including continentality, growing degrees days above 5°C and January temperature. In general, low winter temperatures prevailed at the start of the Holocene, followed by an increase during the early Holocene. Maximum winter temperatures were observed in the mid Holocene, followed by a decline during the late Holocene. The results further indicate that both central and eastern Fennoscandia have become progressively more continental during the last 7000 years, likely because of winter cooling.

Unlike Fennoscandia to the north, insight into the Holocene climate history in Denmark is more limited. This limitation is a consequence of the high degree of historical anthropogenic landscape modification that has occurred in Denmark. Starting c. 6000 years ago, the introduction of agriculture in Denmark had a marked effect on the Danish landscape as the natural virgin forest that characterized the country was progressively cleared and replaced by farmland (Hannon et al., 2000; Iversen, 1941, 1973; Odgaard and Rasmussen, 2000; Rasmussen, 2005). Since then, continued human action has further modified the natural state of the landscape and ecosystems, culminating in a cultural landscape that is one of the most human-impacted in Europe. One result of this historical human activity was a decoupling of any equilibrium between vegetation and climate in Denmark. Consequently, while it remains possible to use fossil pollen records to reconstruct how the Danish landscape and ecosystems have changed through time, it is extremely difficult to reconstruct how the climate has changed because of the strong human factor. In response, there are no long-term quantitative climate reconstructions available for Denmark. Instead, insight into the long-term history of climate in Denmark is largely based on several investigations that used qualitative approaches (Aaby, 1976; Barber et al., 2004; Hede et al., 2010; Iversen, 1973), revealing that both temperature and precipitation have oscillated considerably during the Holocene. At a coarser spatial scale, additional insight into the Holocene climate history of Denmark is available from continental-scale quantitative climate reconstructions (Cheddadi et al., 1997; Davis et al., 2003) and climate model simulations (COHMAP, 1988; Renssen et al., 2005, 2009). In general, these investigations reveal that cooler temperatures prevailed near the start of the Holocene in northern Europe, followed by a thermal maximum interval and decreasing temperatures during the late Holocene.

The overall aim of this investigation is to produce high-resolution quantitative Holocene temperature reconstructions for southern Scandinavia. The specific objectives are (1) to quantitatively reconstruct how mean July temperature (TJul) and mean January temperature (TJan) have changed in both southern Sweden and Denmark during the Holocene and (2) to generate the first high-resolution spatio-temporal TJul and TJan maps for all of Denmark. Considering that climate is predicted to change dramatically in the near future (IntergovernmentaI Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), 2007), the reconstruction will aid in establishing important baseline reference conditions for southern Scandinavia.

sec.title: Study area
sec.p: Denmark is the smallest and most southern country in Scandinavia (Figure 1). It is both flat and low lying, with a mean elevation of 31 m above sea level and a maximum elevation of 171 m. For the interval 1961–1990, the mean annual temperature for Denmark was 7.7°C whereas mean annual precipitation equaled 712 mm (Cappelen and Christensen, 2005). There is notable annual variation in temperature, with July temperature (c. 15°C) markedly higher compared with January temperature (c. 0°C). Winds are typically westerly, with mild and humid conditions prevailing in the winter and cool and variable conditions in the summer. However, the maritime climate can yield to more continental conditions (cold, dry winters and hot, dry summers) when the winds are easterly or southerly. The Danish Meteorological Institute maintains an extensive network of modern weather stations distributed throughout Denmark. For the interval 1961–1990, reliable temperature recordings were made at 28 stations, excluding the island of Bornholm which is located further to the east in the Baltic Sea (Laurensen et al., 1999).

caption.p: Location map showing the proximity of Lake Trehörningen in southwestern Sweden to Denmark. The locations of the various meteorological stations that were used in the analyses are also shown

sec.p: Given that Holocene proxy records in Denmark reveal a significant cultural signal that precludes quantitative climate reconstruction, it is essential that an alternative record be sought to aid any climate reconstruction. This record should contain a profile of natural landscape development, herald from a region with a climate similar to that of Denmark and share a common climate history. One site that satisfies these criteria is Lake Trehörningen (58.33°N, 11.36°E) in southwestern Sweden (Figure 1; Antonsson and Seppä, 2007). The recently published pollen diagram from Lake Trehörningen reveals that the landscape was not dramatically influenced by people in the past, but rather that it evolved naturally. Furthermore, the climate around Lake Trehörningen is clearly comparable to that of Denmark (Christensen et al., 1998), with both regions exhibiting a cool temperate climate with a minor east–west trending precipitation gradient. The similarity in climate is not surprising given that Lake Trehörningen is located only c. 100 km northeast of northern Denmark. Given the similarity in modern climate coupled with the proximity of Lake Trehörningen to Denmark, it is anticipated that these areas also share a common climate history that is separate from the differences in historical cultural impacts. Indeed, vegetation records from both regions appear remarkably similar, with several tree species such as Betula, Pinus, Corylus, Ulmus, Quercus, Alnus, Tilia and Fraxinus exhibiting comparable patterns of historical occurrence (Andersen, 1995; Digerfeldt, 1982; Odgaard, 1994). Consequently, the fossil record from Lake Trehörningen represents the closest site to Denmark that is well suited to aid the quantitative reconstruction of Holocene temperature in Denmark.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A 500 cm long sediment core was recovered from Lake Trehörningen (Antonsson and Seppä, 2007). Eleven radiocarbon dates were obtained, calibrated into calendar years using CALIB 4.3 (Stuiver and Reimer, 1993) and used to develop an age–depth model for the basin. The oldest sample dated to 10 660 cal. BP. The core was subsampled in 4–8 cm intervals for pollen analysis, accomplished using standard techniques (Moore et al., 1991).

Previously, Antonsson and Seppä (2007) used a calibration function that consisted of 137 modern pollen surface samples from Sweden, Finland and Estonia to reconstruct mean annual temperature at Lake Trehörningen. In this contribution, a modern pollen–climate calibration set was used to reconstruct temporal trends in both TJul and TJan at Lake Trehörningen. The calibration set consists of pollen surface samples from 304 lakes distributed throughout Norway, Sweden and Finland.

Pollen grains are well suited for use in the calibration set because they readily record spatial changes in modern plant communities (along climate gradients) and preserve well in the fossil record. The modern pollen data are expressed as percentages and were square-root transformed to stabilize the variance. Modern TJul and TJan values for the interval 1961–1990 were determined for each lake basin in the calibration set by interpolation from the nearest weather station, with the temperatures adjusted for differences in elevation. The predictive performance of the TJul calibration set is good, with a root mean square error of prediction of 0.99°C, a maximum bias of 3.89°C, and a R2 between observed and predicted values of 0.73. In contrast, the predictive performance of the TJan calibration set is not as good as the TJul calibration set, with a root mean square error of prediction of 2.34°C, a maximum bias of 2.13°C, and a R2 between observed and predicted values of 0.76. All of these performance statistics are based on leave-one-out cross-validation (Birks, 1995; Birks and Seppä, 2004; Birks et al., 2010). Pollen- TJul and pollen- TJan calibration functions were subsequently developed using two-component weighted averaging partial least-squares (WA-PLS) regression (Birks and Seppä, 2004; Seppä and Birks, 2001). The calibration functions were used to transform the fossil pollen record from Lake Trehörningen into temporal (multidecadal to centennial) estimates of TJul and TJan, respectively, with sample specific errors of prediction based on 1000 Monte Carlo simulations. The reconstructions were converted into temporal anomaly profiles relative to the nearest weather station, Svarteborg (TJul = 15.7°C; TJan = −3.1°C; Alexandersson and Karlström, 2001), thereby revealing the amount that past TJul and TJan deviated from modern values. The annual amplitude of mean monthly temperature (TJul− TJan), which provides a measure of continentality (Giesecke et al., 2008), was likewise determined in order to assess how the continental-maritime setting at Lake Trehörningen has changed through time.

To evaluate the suitability of using the TJul and TJan anomaly profiles from Lake Trehörningen in Denmark, modern temperature records from both regions were compared, as were palaeoecological records. To facilitate the modern regional temperature comparison, 1961–1990 TJul and TJan recordings from the Svarteborg meteorological station at Lake Trehörningen were compared with the corresponding recordings at each of the 28 meteorological stations in Denmark (Figure 1, Table 1) using linear regression. The resultant slope and R2 values revealed the correlation between the meteorological stations. In comparison, regional trends in Holocene temperature change were assessed using previously published palaeoenvironmental data.

fn.p: Note that the Svarteborg station is located in southern Sweden whereas all other stations are located in Denmark. The slope and R2 values are based on the linear regression between the Svarteborg station and each station in Denmark.

sec.p: To facilitate the TJul and TJan reconstruction in Denmark, the respective anomaly profiles from Lake Trehörningen were applied to each of the 28 meteorological stations in Denmark, and multiplied by the corresponding slope coefficient for each station, yielding corresponding TJul and TJan profiles unique to each site. Insomuch, the slope adjustment accounted for the spatial variability of temperature in Denmark relative to the Svarteborg meteorological station through time, whereby slope values <1 reveal that the change in temperature was greater at Svarteborg compared with the corresponding meteorological station in Denmark, slope values =1 reveal that the change in temperature was equal at both sites and slope values >1 reveal that the change in temperature was greater in Denmark. The slope adjustments are assumed to remain constant throughout the Holocene because of the relative proximity of southern Sweden to Denmark. The resulting 28 temperature profiles were then averaged to generate composite Holocene TJul and TJan profiles for Denmark.

To produce Holocene climate maps for Denmark, a mean value for each 1000 year interval was obtained from each of the 28 TJul and TJan profiles, respectively. Owing to uncertainty in ascertaining an accurate topographic temperature lapse rate for Denmark (i.e. dry rate = 0.1°C/100 m; wet rate = 0.5°C/100 m), as well as in identifying any changes in the lapse rate through time, TJul and TJan maps were produced by a least square fit, with the assumption that temperature fields in Denmark are spatially continuous. This approach involved developing a mathematical function that is assumed to depend linearly on elevation [Z (m)], latitude [Lat (°N)] and longitude [Long (°E)] to predict temperature. The temperature function is: [T(Z,Lat,Long) = (D+C(Z)+ B(Lat)+A(Long))] where A, B, C and D are separate coefficients that were calculated for modern conditions as well as for each 1000 year time interval during the Holocene (Table 2). The only exception is at the start of the Holocene, where the coefficients were determined for a slightly longer interval (1500 years) from 10 000 to 11 500 cal. BP. The model coefficients represent the variation in the absolute values of the temperature parameterization and change through time. The function was implemented in ArcGIS 9.0®, a geographic information system developed by ESRI (Environmental Systems Research Institute, Inc.). Elevation was obtained from a digital elevation model of Denmark with a grid cell size of 500 m, with each cell possessing unique spatial reference coordinates (i.e. Lat and Long). Although Denmark is relatively flat, it is important to account for changes in elevation. For example, the reconstructed temperature value at the point of maximum elevation (171 m) would be 0.85°C warmer if changes in elevation were not considered, assuming a wet temperature lapse rate.

sec.title: Lake Trehörningen reconstruction
sec.p: At Lake Trehörningen, the modern reconstructed TJul value determined using the pollen calibration set overestimates the modern observed value by 1.0°C, whereas the modern reconstructed TJan value underestimates the modern observed value by 0.8°C (Figure 2). In both cases, the modern reconstructed values fall within 1 standard deviation, thus validating the calibration functions. At the start of the Holocene (11 500 cal. BP), TJul was initially low (c. 12.7°C) at Lake Trehörningen (Figure 2). This value is 3°C cooler compared with the 1961–1990 TJul normal recorded at the Svarteborg meteorological station (15.7°C). Thereafter, TJul gradually increased from a low of 13.6 to 17.8°C during the early-Holocene interval from 11 500 to 8000 cal. BP. Maximum TJul values (c. 18°C) occurred during the mid Holocene from 8000 to 4500 cal. BP. Within this interval, TJul values were consistently >18°C between c. 6700 and 5400 cal. BP, with the highest value (19.2°C) occurring at 6450 cal. BP. Relative to modern, mean TJul was 2.6°C warmer than present from 8000 to 4500 cal. BP, though increasing to 3°C between c. 6700 and 5400 cal. BP. TJul then decreased during the late Holocene (4500 cal. BP–present), ranging between 15.7 and17.7°C and averaging 16.9°C.

caption.p: (a) Inferred Holocene TJul and (b) TJan at Lake Trehörningen (solid lines), including 1 standard deviation sample specific errors of prediction (dashed lines). The horizontal dotted lines represent the modern temperature values from the nearest weather station, Svarteborg. (c) The annual amplitude of mean monthly temperature. A smoothed curve (dashed line) was fitted to the data using a locally weighted (10% of data) least squares error approach. The dotted horizontal line represents the modern mean monthly temperature difference

sec.p: Regarding TJan, values were likewise initially low (c. −12.5°C) at the start of the Holocene, corresponding to a 9°C reduction in temperature relative to modern (Figure 2). TJan steadily increased between 11 500 and 9900 cal. BP, leveling at c. −2.6°C between 9900 and 8000 cal. BP. At 8000 cal. BP, after ~1900 years of relative stability, TJan suddenly increased by 3°C within a century, ushering in a mid-Holocene period of winter warmth from 8000 to 4500 cal. BP. During this interval, TJan intermittently increased above freezing, ranging from −1.3 to 2.3°C and averaging 0°C. During the late-Holocene interval, TJan gradually decreased through time, dropping below freezing at 4200 cal. BP. During this interval, TJan values ranged between −0.5 and −3.9°C and averaged −2.1°C.

The annual amplitude of mean monthly temperature has varied at Lake Trehörningen throughout the Holocene (Figure 2). The greatest annual amplitude (25.2°C) occurred at the start of the Holocene at 11 500 cal. BP. Values then steadily decreased through time, with the lowest annual amplitude (16.9°C) occurring at 6450 cal. BP. Thereafter, values gradually increased, with the modern reconstructed annual amplitude (20.6°C) overestimating the modern observed value (18.8°C).

sec.title: Regional patterns
sec.p: The regressions derived using measured TJul and TJan data from the Svarteborg meteorological station in southwestern Sweden and the 28 meteorological stations in Denmark reveal a strong correlation that is characterized by a pattern of near-linearity for the interval 1961–1990 (Table 1). For TJul, slope values <1 were recorded at all stations except two, with values ranging between 0.8 and 1.02, and averaging 0.92. The two stations with slopes >1 were not juxtaposed (Figure 3), with one station located in eastern Denmark (slope = 1.01) and the other in western Denmark (slope = 1.02). The R2 values range between 0.69 and 0.95, with a mean of 0.81. A spatial trend, however, is evident as the coefficients of determination generally decrease from north to south (Figure 3). The highest values occur at the four northernmost stations (range 0.91–0.95; mean 0.93) in western Denmark that are located closest to the Svarteborg meteorological station. In contrast, the stations located in central Denmark have R2 values ranging between 0.82 and 0.88 (mean 0.85), whereas the southernmost stations typically have lower values (range 0.72–0.80; mean 0.75). The lowest R2 value (0.69) heralds from the easternmost meteorological station. Regarding TJan, slope values <1 were noted at all stations, with values ranging between 0.59 and 0.81, and averaging 0.69. R2 values ranged between 0.87 and 0.96, with a mean of 0.91. A weak spatial trend is likewise noted in the TJan coefficients of determination (Figure 3), with northern stations exhibiting marginally higher values (mean 0.94) compared with southern stations (mean 0.89). Combined, these data reveal that both TJul and TJan values are comparable across the study area, with a slightly greater correlation in northern Denmark compared with southern Denmark.

caption.p: Spatial pattern of R2 and slope values for the linear regressions between Svarteborg in southern Sweden and the Danish meteorological stations (1961–1990 climate normals) for (a) TJul and (b) TJan

sec.p: The general pollen-deduced vegetational development in southern Sweden (e.g. Antonsson and Seppä, 2007; Giesecke, 2005) and Denmark (e.g. Andersen, 1995; Iversen, 1973; Odgaard, 1994) suggests a comparable climatic trend during the early and mid Holocene. During the early Holocene, the vegetation in both Denmark and southern Sweden consisted of cold-tolerant Pinus and Betula dominated woodlands. In comparison, both regions appear to be characterized by warm climate conditions during the mid Holocene as evidenced by the expansion of thermophilous taxa such as Corylus, Ulmus, Quercus, Alnus, Tilia and Fraxinus. This overall similarity suggests that both southern Sweden and Denmark were likely influenced by the same climate forcing mechanisms, illustrating the suitability of using the temperature records from Lake Trehörningen in Denmark. In contrast to the preceding intervals, it is more difficult to discern and compare the late-Holocene climate because of the significant human impact on the vegetation in Denmark (Hannon et al., 2000; Iversen, 1973; Odgaard and Rasmussen, 2000; Rasmussen, 2005).

sec.title: Temperature reconstruction in Denmark
sec.p: The composite climate profile (Figure 4) and maps (Figure 5) for Denmark reveal that TJul gradually increased during the early Holocene from 13°C at the start of the Holocene (11 500 cal. BP) to maximum values 18–19°C between c. 8000 and 4500 cal. BP. During the last 4500 years, TJul has decreased, generally ranging between 16 and 17°C. At the top of the profile, the reconstructed composite TJu value (16.7°C) exceeds the 1961–1990 mean TJul normal value for Denmark (15.8°C; see Table 1 for individual station values) by 0.9°C. Regarding the TJul maps, the low root mean square difference and high correlation values (Table 2) indicate that the model parameterization adequately describes TJul in Denmark. While the maps are in agreement with the temporal reconstruction, they additionally reveal a weak temperature gradient across Denmark, with eastern Denmark being slightly warmer compared with western Denmark.

sec.p: With regards to TJan (Figures 4 and 6), cold winter conditions (c. −6°C) prevailed in Denmark at the start of the Holocene. Thereafter, TJan increased between 11 500 and 9900 cal. BP, leveling at c. 0.6°C between 9900 and 8000 cal. BP. A notable increase in TJan (c. 2°C) is observed at 8000 cal. BP, followed by the establishment of generally mild conditions from 8000 to 4500 cal. BP. During this interval, TJan was consistently above freezing, averaging 2.4°C. In Denmark, the late-Holocene interval was characterized by a long-term cooling trend, with TJan reaching 0°C at c. 1600 cal. BP and decreasing by c. 2°C through time. At the top of the profile, reconstructed TJan (−0.3°C) underestimates the 1961–1990 mean TJul normal (0.3°C; Table 1) by 0.6°C. Regarding the TJan maps (Figure 6), the generally low root mean square difference and high correlation values (Table 2) indicate that the model parameterization adequately describes TJan in Denmark. Unlike the TJul maps, no broad-scale spatial gradients are evident in the TJan maps. Instead, spatial variations in TJan track changes in elevation and occur along short coastal–inland gradients.

caption.p: Mean 1000 yr interval spatio-temporal TJan maps of Denmark. The palaeoshoreline configuration is the same as in Figure 5

sec.title: Regional temperature comparison
sec.p: Regionally, present-day TJul is highly comparable between Lake Trehörningen (15.7°C at Svarteborg meteorological station; Table 1) and Denmark (mean 15.8°C from 28 meterological stations). Comparing the TJul reconstructions from Lake Trehörningen and Denmark reveals that there has been little regional difference in TJul throughout the Holocene (Figure 7). In contrast, present-day observed TJan is lower at Svarteborg (−3.1°C) compared with Denmark (0.3°C mean from 28 stations). A comparison of the TJan reconstructions reveals that winter temperatures have been consistently lower at Lake Trehörningen compared with Denmark throughout the Holocene. Furthermore, the regional difference in TJan has varied through time. The greatest difference (c. 6°C) occurred at the start of the Holocene, whereas during the early Holocene (11 500–9900 cal. BP) the regional difference in TJan decreased from c. 5°C to 3°C. Thereafter, the regional difference in TJan remained at about 3°C until 8000 cal. BP. Between 8000 and 4000 cal. BP, the regional difference was at a minimum, averaging 2.4°C. Starting at 4000 cal. BP, the regional difference in TJan increased through time to the present-day value in the top-most sediment core sample (3.6°C).

caption.p: Reconstructed temperature difference between Lake Trehörningen and the composite Danish curves. The dotted horizontal line is the modern observed difference in TJul, whereas the horizontal dashed line is the modern observed difference in TJan

sec.title: Holocene temperature history in southern Scandinavia
sec.p: Temporally, the temperature reconstructions from Lake Trehörningen (southwestern Sweden) and in Denmark (Figures 2 and 4) exhibit a pattern of change that is generally comparable with other temperature reconstructions in Fennoscandia (Antonsson et al., 2006, 2008; Bjune et al., 2004, 2005; Hammarlund et al., 2003; Nesje 2009; Ojala et al., 2008; Seppä and Birks, 2001; Seppä et al., 2005, 2009a; Velle et al., 2005). The lowest Holocene temperatures prevailed at the start of the Holocene, when the Scandinavian Ice Sheet still covered most of Fennoscandia (Björck, 2008). At this time, areas that were free of ice, though still near the ice margin, include western Norway, southern Sweden, eastern Finland and the Kola Peninsula in Russia, as well as Denmark. Indeed, according to Antonsson and Seppä (2007), the ice-margin was located only 100 km north of Lake Trehörningen at 11 000 cal. BP, illustrating the proximity of the ice sheet to the study area. At the start of the Holocene, the Scandinavian Ice Sheet was sufficiently large to support anticyclonic circulation, fostering cool-cold climatic conditions and strong katabatic winds near the ice-margin (Seppä and Birks, 2001), consistent with the reconstructed low temperatures and higher measure of continentality as evidenced by the relatively large amplitude in the mean monthly temperature record (Figures 2 and 7). In consequence, cold-tolerant pioneering vegetation such as Betula and Pinus persisted in both southern Sweden and Denmark at the start of the Holocene (Andersen, 1995; Giesecke, 2005; Odgaard, 1994).

In contrast to the conditions at the start of the Holocene, temperatures gradually increased throughout Fennoscandia during the early Holocene (11 500–8000 cal. BP; Antonsson et al., 2006, 2008; Bjune et al., 2004, 2005; Ojala et al., 2008; Seppä and Birks, 2001; Seppä et al., 2005, 2009a). At both Lake Trehörningen and in Denmark, TJul increased steadily during this interval, whereas TJan initially increased and then leveled out at 9900 cal. BP. The general rise in temperature was accompanied by a reduction in the amplitude of the mean monthly temperature record (Figures 2 and 4), likely in response to changes in winter temperature (Figure 7), suggesting that a maritime climate developed around southern Sweden and Denmark at this time. In response to the increased warmth and maritime setting, the composition of the forests changed as thermophilous vegetation such as Corylus and Ulmus expanded (Andersen, 1995; Giesecke, 2005; Odgaard, 1994). The increase in these taxa is significant because it implies that maritime conditions with mild winter temperatures, that did not limit tree growth or cause mortality, prevailed. In addition, at 9800 cal. BP the European pond turtle (Emys orbicularis) expanded northward from the Balkans into both southern Sweden and Denmark (Degerbøl and Krog, 1951; Sommer et al., 2009). The expansion of the European pond turtle is significant because the species is summer-temperature sensitive, requiring warm conditions for the incubation of its clutches. Consequently, its presence in southern Sweden and Denmark substantiates that warm summer conditions prevailed at this time.

Several factors have been invoked to explain the rise in temperature during the early Holocene, including external forcings such as insolation. Maximum annual and summer (June–August) insolation occurred during the early Holocene in mid northern latitudes (Berger and Loutre, 1991), and thus must have warmed the Scandinavian subcontinent at that time (COHMAP, 1988; Renssen et al., 2005). In addition to directly warming the subcontinent, the higher insolation would have also warmed the surrounding North and Baltic seas, which in turn may have partially buffered against large changes in annual temperature owing to the high heat storage capacity of water. Indeed, on the basis of oxygen isotope records from lake sediments, it has been suggested that strong zonal flow associated with vigorous Atlantic meridional overturning circulation and higher sea-surface temperatures in the eastern North Atlantic Ocean moderated the climate in southern Sweden during the early Holocene (Heikkilä et al., 2010; Jonsson et al., 2010; Seppä et al., 2005). Another factor that may have contributed to the early-Holocene warming trend is the Scandinavian Ice Sheet, which was rapidly melting at that time (Björck, 2008). The progressive loss of mass would have weakened the anticyclonic conditions that previously prevailed over the ice sheet and decreased the overall landsurface albedo (Betts and Ball, 1997; Hartman, 1994), both of which would have contributed positively to the warming trend.

Regarding the inflection in TJan at 9900 cal. BP (Figures 2 and 4), it should be noted that the time of the inflection generally coincides with low January insolation at c. 10 000 cal. BP. Thus, perhaps the inflection is related to the combined effect of lower winter insolation, which should have caused cooling, and strong zonal flow which would have buffered the annual temperature cycle. Another unique point in time from the early-Holocene interval that has received considerable interest in northern Europe is the 8.2 ka cold event. This event has been reported at many sites in northern Europe, especially those near the temperate-boreal forest ecotone in Sweden, Finland and Estonia (Seppä et al., 2007, 2009a), as well as in Denmark (Hede et al., 2010). At Lake Trehörningen, a previous investigation (Antonsson and Seppä, 2007) that focused on reconstructing annual temperature likewise documented a decline in temperature between 8200 and 8000 cal. BP, whereas in this study no notable decline is evident. This discrepancy is likely related to the nature of the calibration functions that were used in the two studies, whereby the difference in the climatic gradients covered by the surface samples probably affected the output of the models. The calibration function based on 304 lakes used in this investigation is probably less sensitive to the subtle pollen stratigraphic changes that occurred at Lake Trehörningen between 8200 and 8000 cal. BP compared with the 137-lake calibration function used by Antonsson and Seppä (2007).

At both Lake Trehörningen and in Denmark, maximum TJul and TJan are observed during the mid Holocene interval (8000–4500 cal. BP; Figures 2 and 4). While warm in both summer and winter, the mean monthly temperature difference attained its lowest values during the Holocene (Figure 2), implying that that a maritime climate still prevailed at this time, consistent with other sites in Fennoscandia (Giesecke et al., 2008). Indeed, studies aimed at reconstructing changes in sea level in southern Scandinavia indicate that sea levels were higher than present at this time (Berglund et al., 2005; Christensen et al., 1997), which may have contributed to the prevailing maritime conditions. The observation of maximum warmth is very consistent with other temperature reconstructions in Fennoscandia that reveal a thermal maximum interval between c. 8000 and 4800 cal. BP (Seppä et al., 2009a). For example, many chironomid-based temperature records show that the mid Holocene was the warmest interval during the Holocene in Fennoscandia (Rosén et al., 2001; Seppä et al., 2002; Velle et al., 2005). Likewise, in southwestern Norway, the Jostedalsbreen ice cap, constituting the largest ice cap in continental Europe, may have disappeared during this interval (Nesje and Kvamme, 1991). In addition, records of lake-level fluctuations reveal that water levels were markedly lower during the mid Holocene in south-central Sweden compared with both the early and late Holocene, likely in response to increasing temperature and/or decreasing humidity (Almquist-Jacobson, 1995; Digerfeldt, 1988; Hammarlund et al., 2003). Vegetation composition also changed at this time as Tilia and Quercus both increased in abundance in southern Sweden and Denmark (Andersen, 1995; Giesecke, 2005), signifying high summer temperatures and increased summer drought. The persistence of both Corylus, which in modern-day Scandinavia is a moderately oceanic species (Andersson, 1902; Dahl, 1998; Giesecke et al., 2008; Hintikka, 1963) and Ulmus, similarly oceanic but with a wider climatic tolerance, during this interval further suggests that winter temperatures were mild.

It has been suggested that the warm mid-Holocene climate is related to anticyclonic synoptic conditions (Antonsson et al., 2008), whereby the establishment of persistent high-pressure cells over the Scandinavian Peninsula intensified the meridional flow, drawing warm southern and southeastern air into northern Europe during the summer. In addition to augmenting the introduction of warm air into northern Europe, the high-pressure cells also redirected zonal flow, inhibiting the delivery of cool moist Atlantic air to the region (Antonsson et al., 2008; Chen and Hällström, 1999; Seppä et al., 2005). Under such prevailing atmospheric conditions, the mean summer water temperature was also higher than present-day (Enghoff et al., 2007; Petersen, 2004; Vork and Thomsen, 1996), which regulated the annual temperate cycle and contributed to winter warmth. Consequently, warm-demanding fish, mollusc and ostracod species persisted in the coastal waters around Denmark, co-habitating with several species that are now considered to be more boreal (Enghoff et al., 2007; Petersen, 2004; Vork and Thomsen, 1996). After several millennia, the warm conditions started to wane, as evidenced by reformation and expansion of glaciers in the Jostedalsbreen region (Nesje and Kvamme, 1991; Nesje et al., 2001), as well as the local extinction of the European pond turtle in southern Sweden at 5500 cal. BP (Sommer et al., 2009). Given that the European pond turtle requires warm summer temperatures for the incubation of its clutches, its extinction implies that summer temperature must have decreased at this time. Interestingly, the timing of the extinction corresponds with the end of consistently high (>18°C) TJul at Lake Trehörningen (5400 cal. BP; Figure 2), thus providing additional evidence that the initial onset of summer cooling began at this time.

As with other sites in Fennoscandia (Antonsson et al., 2008; Giesecke et al., 2008; Seppä et al., 2009a), both TJul and TJan gradually decreased at Lake Trehörningen and in Denmark during the late Holocene (4500 cal. BP to present; Figures 2 and 4). The gradual decrease in temperature corresponds with the long-term decline in both annual and summer insolation in northern latitudes (Berger and Loutre, 1991; Seppä et al., 2009a). While still maritime, the small increase in the mean monthly temperature difference (Figure 2) implies that conditions became slightly more continental relative to the preceding mid-Holocene interval, possibly in response to changing winter temperature (Figure 7). In southern Sweden, the abundance of thermophilous vegetation declined (Giesecke, 2005) in response to the decreasing temperature (Seppä et al., 2005). This decline was further exacerbated by increased competition with the southward-expanding continental-tree, Picea abies (Giesecke, 2005; Giesecke and Bennett, 2004). A similar decrease in thermophilous taxa is likewise evident in Denmark (Andersen, 1995), though in Denmark the decline is not generally related to changes in climate (Figures 4 and 5) or competition. Instead, it is associated with a profound increase in cultural activity, whereby the forests were cleared in order to create arable and pastureland (Hannon et al., 2000; Odgaard and Rasmussen, 2000; Rasmussen, 2005).

sec.title: Spatio-temporal temperature maps
sec.p: In Scandinavia, palaeoecological studies have been used to map and describe the spatio-temporal distribution of both individual tree species (Bradshaw and Lindbladh, 2005; Giesecke and Bennett, 2004) and plant communities (Nielsen and Odgaard, 2005; Seppä et al., 2009b). These investigations generated insight into the spatial pattern of postglacial forest development and helped to identify some key processes that were influential in the development of the forested landscape (Bradshaw and Lindbladh, 2005; Bradshaw et al., 2010; Giesecke and Bennett, 2004; Seppä et al., 2009b). In contrast, insight into the spatio-temporal pattern of climate change in Scandinavia has largely been generated using either continental-scale climate reconstructions (Cheddadi et al., 1997; Davis et al., 2003), model simulations (COHMAP, 1988; Renssen et al., 2005, 2009), or collated paleoclimatic reconstructions (Antonsson et al., 2008; Bjune et al., 2004; Giesecke et al., 2008; Kaplan and Wolfe, 2006; Seppä et al., 2009a). Regarding the latter, relatively few studies have produced spatially continuous Holocene climate maps (Brown et al., 2006).

The Holocene temperature maps of Denmark (Figures 5, 6) represent the first spatio-temporal temperature reconstructions in northern Europe that were derived using the approach described herein. Insomuch, the approach has the capacity to spatially expand two-dimensional (fixed space and time) climate reconstructions into four-dimensions (X, Y, Z and time). Assuming that the established temperature function parameterization is valid for a range of elevations, the approach is also capable of aiding quantitative reconstruction at high elevations, a traditionally challenging endeavor because of upslope transport of pollen (Birks and Seppä, 2004; Birks et al., 2010; Brown et al., 2008) and the limited number of meteorological stations typically located at higher elevations. In consequence, it should be possible to adapt the approach to other areas in Scandinavia (and elsewhere), including those areas that currently lack quantitative climate reconstructions.

While a strong modern correlation of temperature exists between the Svarteborg meteorological station and the 28 meteorological stations in Denmark (Figure 3), spatial variations in the coefficient of determination between stations reveal that confidence in the reconstructions is spatially non-uniform. In both the TJul and TJan maps, increased confidence is ascribed to the northern parts of the country because the highest coefficients of determination are located in that region (Figure 3). This pattern is not surprising, given the greater proximity of northern Denmark to the Svarteborg meteorological station in southwestern Sweden. From a temporal perspective, the overall level of confidence in the accuracy of the maps should decrease for past intervals because the modern high correlations may not be invariant through time, though this cannot be tested.

Spatially, the weak east–west decreasing summer temperature gradient evident in the TJul maps of Denmark (Figure 5) is likely related to a maritime effect influencing the local climate (Laursen et al., 1999). It is posited that eastern Denmark is slightly warmer in the summer compared with western Denmark because of its greater proximity to warm water in the southwestern Baltic Sea basin (Janssen et al., 1999). Slightly cooler temperatures prevail in western Denmark because the climate in that part of the country is influenced by relatively cool waters in the central and northern North Sea. During the early Holocene, the influence of such water bodies on local climate is more ambiguous. For example, the Scandinavian Ice Sheet was still melting at that time and thus contributing cold meltwater to the non-marine Baltic basin, particularly in the north (Björck, 1995, 2008). This input of cold water may have been offset somewhat by higher summer insolation (Berger and Loutre, 1991), which would have warmed the surface layer. Assuming that water circulation was restricted at this time, cold northern water would not have readily flowed southward, allowing water warmed by irradiance to accumulate in the southwestern basin next to Denmark. Another factor likely contributing to the observed summer temperature gradient is the prevailing westerly air flow, which first encounters the west coast of Denmark. Consequently, this region has more cloud and precipitation, as well as less sunshine, compared with eastern Denmark.

In contrast to TJul, the TJan maps reveal that TJan is relatively more uniform across Denmark with no broad-scale winter temperature gradients evident (Figure 6). However, slight spatial variations in temperature are spatially apparent. In general, coastal areas appear slightly warmer compared with the inland environment, likely because the surrounding seas generate a warm water heat buffer around Denmark (Janssen et al., 1999) that partially regulates the winter temperature. In addition, another factor that also appears to influence winter temperature is topography. Several coastal regions in northern, central and eastern Denmark are characterized by slightly higher elevations compared with the rest of the country. Notably, these areas are also typified by cooler temperatures, regardless of their proximity to the coast.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The history of Holocene temperature change was quantitatively reconstructed at Lake Trehörningen, southern Sweden, using a modern pollen–climate calibration set. In Denmark, however, the possibility of using such a calibration set to reconstruct Holocene temperature history is problematic because of the high degree of historical anthropogenic landscape modification. Consequently, the reconstructed temperature record from Lake Trehörningen was spatially transformed in order to generate composite temperature curves and four-dimensional temperature maps for Denmark.

In both southern Sweden and in Denmark, modern reconstructed temperatures are within 1 standard deviation of observed values, validating the pollen–temperature calibration functions. In both regions, TJul was low (c. 13°C) at the start of the Holocene, followed by a warming trend between 11 500 and 8000 cal. BP and the onset of maritime climatic conditions. Maximum warmth occurred during the mid-Holocene interval (8000–4500 cal. BP), with TJul typically ≥18°C, corresponding to a temperature increase of ≥2°C relative to modern. In contrast to the mid Holocene, TJul gradually decreased during the late-Holocene interval. Regarding TJan, cold conditions prevailed at the start of the Holocene at Lake Trehörningen (c. −12°C) and in Denmark (c. −6°C), followed by a warming trend between 11 500 and 9900 cal. BP. From 9900 to 8000 cal. BP, TJan was relatively stable, averaging −2.6 and 0.6°C, respectively. Thereafter, maximum TJan values are observed between 8000 and 4500 cal. BP. During this interval, TJan ranged between −1.3 and 2.6°C (average 0°C) at Lake Trehörningen, whereas in Denmark TJan was consistently above freezing, averaging 2.5°C. TJan gradually decreased during the late Holocene. Spatially, the reconstructed TJul maps show that a weak east–west decreasing temperature gradient occurs in Denmark, likely related to a maritime effect. No such gradient is evident in the TJan maps, though slight temperature variations are evident along coastal–inland and topographic gradients.
